content:
The Act titled "Drug Trafficking Elimination Act of 2007" includes criminal enhancements for unlawful manufacturing, distributing, dispensing, or possessing large amounts of heroin, marijuana, and methamphetamine. Section 401(b)(1) of the Controlled Substances Act is amended to include increased penalties for violations involving large quantities of heroin, marijuana, and methamphetamine. The Controlled Substances Act is amended to increase penalties for violations involving large quantities of heroin, marijuana, and methamphetamine, with a minimum 20-year prison sentence for offenders. SEC. 102. Criminal enhancements for unlawful importation and exportation of large amounts of heroin, marijuana, and methamphetamine include a minimum 20-year prison sentence for offenders. Section 1010(b) of the Controlled Substances Import and Export Act is amended to include harsher penalties for violations involving large quantities of heroin, marijuana, and methamphetamine. Offenders will face the same penalties as under paragraph (1) but with a mandatory minimum prison sentence of 20 years. The amendment to Section 1010(b) of the Controlled Substances Import and Export Act imposes a mandatory minimum prison sentence of 20 years for offenders involved in violations with large quantities of heroin, marijuana, and methamphetamine. SEC. 103. MANUFACTURING CONTROLLED SUBSTANCES ON FEDERAL PROPERTY.

Amendment to the Controlled Substances Act increases penalty to 10 years for manufacturing or cultivating controlled substances on Federal property.

SEC. 104. USE OF HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES ON FEDERAL LAND. SEC. 104. USE OF HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES ON FEDERAL LAND.

Amendment to the Controlled Substances Act imposes up to 5 years imprisonment for knowingly using hazardous substances on Federal land that pose a serious hazard to humans, wildlife, or the environment, in addition to other penalties. SEC. 105. LISTED CHEMICALS.

Amendment to the Controlled Substances Act increases penalties for drug trafficking offenses to 30 years and 20 years for different violations.

SEC. 106. MURDER AND OTHER VIOLENT CRIMES RELATED TO DRUG TRAFFICKING.

New section added to the Controlled Substances Act addresses murder and violent crimes committed in relation to drug trafficking activities. Whoever commits a crime of violence during a drug trafficking crime may face additional punishment, including death or life imprisonment depending on the severity of the violence. The section defines terms related to crimes of violence, drug trafficking, and sexual abuse, specifying venue for prosecution. The section adds definitions for crimes of violence, drug trafficking, and sexual abuse, including the term 'serious bodily injury' as defined in section 1365 of title 18, United States Code. It also introduces a new section on Dangerous Drug Trafficking Organizations. "Dangerous drug trafficking organizations" Any person who knowingly engages in a dangerous drug trafficking organization, defined as a group of 5 or more individuals committing drug trafficking crimes, will face a minimum of 20 years imprisonment. Any person engaging in a dangerous drug trafficking organization, involving multiple violations of drug trafficking laws, faces severe punishment, including a felony charge. Jurisdiction extends extraterritorially for US citizens or lawful residents. Amendments to the Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act of 1970 are made to include these provisions. Title II of the Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act focuses on protecting children from drug traffickers. It includes provisions for punishing those involved in dangerous drug trafficking organizations and distributing drugs to persons under 21 and pregnant individuals. Sec. 418 of the Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act imposes a mandatory minimum sentence of 3 to 10 years for individuals over 18 who distribute controlled substances to those under 21 or pregnant individuals, with exceptions for small amounts of marijuana. The Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act mandates a minimum 3 to 10-year sentence for distributing controlled substances to minors or pregnant individuals. Repeat offenders face 5 to 20 years imprisonment, with third convictions subject to harsher penalties. SEC. 418. Distribution to persons under age 21 and pregnant persons. SEC. 202. Distribution in or near schools. Section 419 of the Controlled Substances Act is amended to address distribution in or near schools. Sec. 419 addresses the distribution, possession, or manufacturing of controlled substances near schools, playgrounds, housing facilities, youth centers, swimming pools, or video arcade facilities, with a mandatory minimum sentence of 3 to 10 years, excluding offenses involving 5 grams or less of marihuana. Sec. 419 outlines penalties for drug offenses near specified locations like schools, playgrounds, and youth centers. Repeat offenders face 5 to 20 years imprisonment. Definitions for "playground" and "youth center" are provided. The text defines terms related to facilities for children, including gymnasiums, video arcade facilities, and swimming pools. SEC. 203 amends Section 420 of the Controlled Substances Act to address the employment or use of persons under 18 years of age in drug operations. Section 420 of the Controlled Substances Act imposes a 3 to 10-year imprisonment term for individuals over 18 who involve minors in drug-related activities or receive controlled substances from minors. Whoever violates subsection (a) after a prior conviction under section 401(a) shall be sentenced to a term of imprisonment of not less than 5 years nor more than 20 years, in addition to any punishment under section 401(b). Penalties for third and subsequent convictions will be governed by section 401(b)(1)(A). SEC. 204 amends the Controlled Substances Act to impose a 5 to 20-year imprisonment term for anyone violating drug-related premises laws involving individuals under 18. SEC. 205 modifies the safety valve provision. SEC. 205 modifies the safety valve provision in the Controlled Substances Act by adding conditions related to drug trafficking organizations and offenses involving children. TITLE III--NATIONAL DRUG TRAFFICKING ENFORCEMENT STRATEGY

SEC. 301. NATIONAL ENFORCEMENT STRATEGY. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary of Homeland Security, will develop a National Drug Trafficking Enforcement Strategy. The Attorney General will submit an annual report to the Senate and House Committees on the Judiciary detailing drug enforcement activities of various federal law enforcement agencies and the allocation of resources for investigating and prosecuting violations of the Controlled Substances Act. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary of Homeland Security, will develop a National Drug Trafficking Enforcement Strategy and submit an annual report to Congress detailing drug enforcement activities and resource allocation for prosecuting violations of the Controlled Substances Act, including those involving significant drug trafficking organizations, importers of controlled substances, and violations endangering children.
